title: Data Minimalism vs. Data Maximalism in Rare Disease Drug Repurposing
assumption: More comprehensive multi-modal datasets always improve repurposing predictions
hypothesis: Minimal but highly curated datasets achieve superior actionable predictions compared to comprehensive multi-modal approaches
evaluationPlan: Controlled comparison between minimal curated dataset (n=500 high-confidence associations) vs maximal dataset (n=50,000+ multi-modal features) using identical ML architectures across 10 rare diseases. Evaluation includes prediction accuracy, clinical actionability score, expert agreement, and implementation feasibility.
implications: Could unlock repurposing for ultra-rare conditions with extremely limited data by focusing on data quality over quantity
relatedWork: Challenges data maximalism assumptions in drug discovery AI literature
milestones: Month 1: Dataset curation, Month 2: Model training, Month 3: Clinical expert evaluation
successCriteria: Minimal datasets show comparable accuracy (±5%) but superior actionability (>20% improvement) and expert acceptance (>60% preference)
notes: Core experiment testing fundamental data assumption

title: Accuracy-First vs. Actionability-First AI Design
assumption: Predictive accuracy is the primary success metric for AI systems
hypothesis: AI systems optimized for clinical actionability produce better real-world outcomes than accuracy-optimized models
evaluationPlan: Deploy both accuracy-optimized and actionability-optimized AI systems with clinical partners. Measure clinical adoption rate, decision confidence, time from prediction to clinical action, and long-term outcomes through randomized deployment.
implications: Could bridge the gap between AI predictions and clinical implementation by prioritizing clinical utility over raw performance metrics
relatedWork: Challenges accuracy-first optimization paradigm in medical AI literature
milestones: Month 1: Actionability framework design, Month 3: Model development, Month 6: Clinical deployment
successCriteria: Actionability-first models achieve >30% higher clinical adoption rate despite potentially 5-10% lower raw accuracy

title: Cross-Disease Pattern Learning vs. Disease-Specific Modeling
assumption: Each rare disease requires custom computational approaches
hypothesis: Meta-learning approaches leveraging shared patterns across rare diseases outperform disease-specific models
evaluationPlan: Implement Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) across 20 rare diseases with varying pathophysiology. Compare few-shot learning performance, cross-disease generalization, and mechanistic interpretability between meta-learned and disease-specific models.
implications: Could enable repurposing for diseases with insufficient individual datasets by leveraging cross-disease mechanistic patterns
relatedWork: Challenges disease-specific modeling assumption in precision medicine literature
milestones: Month 1: Disease selection and data preparation, Month 3: MAML implementation, Month 4: Cross-disease validation
successCriteria: Meta-learning achieves >40% better few-shot performance (<10 examples) and identifies interpretable shared mechanistic patterns

title: Parallel vs. Sequential Validation Strategies
assumption: Drug validation must follow sequential preclinical → clinical stages
hypothesis: Parallel validation using real-world evidence accelerates repurposing without compromising safety
evaluationPlan: Compare time-to-treatment and safety outcomes between traditional sequential validation and parallel validation using real-world evidence, EHR data, and accelerated clinical protocols. Partner with regulatory agencies for acceptance evaluation.
implications: Could dramatically reduce time-to-treatment for rare disease patients while maintaining safety standards
relatedWork: Challenges sequential validation paradigm in drug development literature
milestones: Month 3: Regulatory engagement, Month 6: Parallel framework implementation, Month 12: Outcome comparison
successCriteria: Parallel validation reduces time-to-treatment by 40-60% while maintaining equivalent safety signal detection (>95% sensitivity)
notes: Requires regulatory partnership and long timeline

title: Human-AI Collaboration vs. Fully Automated Approaches
assumption: AI should minimize human bias and replace expert judgment
hypothesis: Hybrid human-AI systems outperform fully automated approaches for complex repurposing decisions
evaluationPlan: Design collaborative interface for clinician-AI drug repurposing decisions. Conduct comparative evaluation study with rare disease experts comparing automated vs collaborative systems on matched clinical scenarios.
implications: Could leverage irreplaceable rare disease expertise while scaling discovery through strategic human-AI collaboration
relatedWork: Challenges AI supremacy assumption in medical decision-making literature
milestones: Month 1: Interface design, Month 2: Expert recruitment, Month 4: Comparative evaluation
successCriteria: Collaborative systems achieve >25% higher decision quality scores and >50% higher clinical implementation rate
notes: Critical for expert acceptance and adoption
